qas.question: What type of antenna has impedance at a specific frequency?
What term can be used to refer to the usable spectrum of an antennas frequency?
What causes the frequencies outside of the bandwidth to be unusable?
What is lessened by the Yagi-Uda design?

context: Although a <a0_0>resonant<a0_0/> antenna has a purely resistive feed-point impedance at a particular frequency, many (if not most) applications require using an antenna over a range of frequencies. An antenna's <a1_0>bandwidth<a1_0/> specifies the range of frequencies over which its performance does not suffer due to a poor <a2_0>impedance match<a2_0/>. Also in the case of a Yagi-Uda array, the use of the antenna very far away from its design frequency reduces the antenna's <a3_0>directivity<a3_0/>, thus reducing the usable bandwidth regardless of impedance matching.
